Award.AwardTitle: ATE Regional Center for Semiconductor and Nanotechnology Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanotechnology and semiconductor manufacturing industries are undergoing continued expansion in the Northeast. An example of this expansion is the recent announcement by New York Governor Cuomo that six leading global technology companies are investing $1.5 billion to develop "Nano Utica", the state's second major hub of nanotechnology research and development, spearheaded by the College of Nanoscale Science and Engineering (CNSE) and the State University of New York Institute of Technology (SUNYIT), creating over 1,000 new high-tech jobs. A highly qualified technical workforce is needed to continue to support the growth of the nanotechnology and semiconductor manufacturing industries in New York State and Western New England.

The Northeast Advanced Technological Education Center (NEATEC) will support the industry workforce needs. NEATEC partners include GlobalFoundries, IBM, General Electric, SEMATECH, Hudson Valley Community College (HVCC), Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI), Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), CNSE, SUNYIT, Mohawk Valley Community College (MVCC), Fulton Montgomery Community College (FMCC), SUNY Adirondack, regional K-12, and additional community colleges in NY, VT, MA, and CT.

NEATEC will implement and enable (1) the expansion of cutting-edge semiconductor and nanotechnology related AAS/AS degree programs among its community college partners, (2) on-the-job co-op and internship-based training, (3) distance learning options and just-in-time education, (4) K-12 career pathway development, (5) the coordination of student recruitment, and (6) research studies on emerging workforce trends and education needs. The Center will improve community college student learning in science and engineering by providing a broader range of students access to the educational materials, facilities and faculty of several premier U.S. science and engineering schools.

The evaluation and assessment plans will inform the wider community about the effectiveness of materials developed in educating a qualified entry-level technical workforce, the knowledge transfer from the center to partner institutions, the performance of program graduates in the field, and the value of the collaborative partnerships established.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Northeast Advanced Technological Education Center (NEATEC) is located at the State University of New York Polytechnic Institute in Albany, New York. The Center was founded in September of 2010, the first renewal A(ward 1555699) started in September 2014 and ended on August 2018 (including a no-cost extension). The Center was structured around six strategic goals.

 

Goal 1: Industrial Workforce Skillset Analysis: A comprehensive comparison of skillsets was undertaken by NEATEC in order to understand and learn about the discrepancies between what is taught in typical community colleges – the main source of technicians needed by the semiconductor and related high-tech industries. The study determined the following set of skill gaps between the industries and what is taught at community colleges

 

  1. Implementing Quality Principles
  2. Troubleshooting and Repairing Pneumatic Systems
  3. Troubleshooting and Repairing Hydraulic Systems
  4. Troubleshooting and Repairing Vacuum Systems
  5. Troubleshooting and Repairing RF Systems
  6. Performing Preventive and Routine Maintenance.

 

Several hands-on  workshops and short courses were created  based in the gap analysis and in the following Industrial Workforce Skillset Analysis:

 

  • Semiconductor manufacturing skillset analysis update
  • Integrated photonics manufacturing skillset analysis
  • Power electronics packaging skillset analysis
  • Photovoltaic (PV) manufacturing skillset analysis
  • LED lighting manufacturing skillset analysis

 

Goal 2: Curricular Development and Implementation To fulfill this goal NEATEC have developed several courses/workshops during the duration of the award include

  1. I.      Courses
  • NEATEC partnered with Fairfield University to start the development of eight nanotechnology courses to community colleges and 4-year colleges: NEATEC redeveloped the content to make them available to two-year colleges. The courses include:  Two Introductory Nanotechnology courses; Two Nanoelectronics courses; Two Nano-Biology Courses; and Two Nano-Chemistry Courses. Westchester Community College has already adopted the first two introductory courses.
  • Supported through NSF supplemental funding, NEATEC, AIM Photonics and OP-TEC are developing a multi-course, 25 credit Certificate in Integrated Photonics Manufacturing (IPM) suitable for 2- and 4-year colleges.

 

  1. II.              Workshops
  • In response to these needs stated in the skillset analyses of Goal 1, NEATEC developed several  topic-specific, hands-on workshops,  including
  1. Basic Vacuum Technology and Advanced Vacuum Component Assembly
  2. Mechatronics and Introduction to Mechatronics Troubleshooting
  3. RF and Plasma Technology
  4. Photovoltaic Technology
  5. Statistical Process Control
  6. Pneumatic Technology
  7. Advanced Manufacturing Practice (AMP).

 

During the period 2014-2018 these workshop were taken by more than 1,200 participants, including students and faculty of 2- and 4-year colleges, technicians of industrial partners, and high-school teacher.

 

 

Goal 3: Teacher and Faculty Development. For community college faculty NEATEC sponsored a range of professional development workshops/colloquia/short courses, as stated in Goal 2.

  • For the grades 7-12 community, NEATEC Learning Modules (NML) were developed together with the NEATEC partner high school teachers. NLM’s included topics on Nanotechnology, Semiconductors, Photovoltaic, Alternate Energy, Mathematics, and general science and technology. These modules are being offered by over 40 schools in New York State. The modules are available to any school in the Nation. Two ancillary documents (pdf file), with the list of all the modules, were included in the Final Report of this Award..

 

Goal 4: Experiential Learning. Two categories of experiential leaning wsere offered: local internships and NIST internships.

  • SUNY Poly, GlobalFoundries and General Electric offer on a regular basis a range of internships, co-ops and job shadowing that benefit many local community college students every year. Six internships per year were awarded for 12-week experiential learning opportunities as 300mm Si wafer fabrication tool process operators.
  • The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) together with NEATEC sponsor nine students every year to participate as interns at the NIST nanotechnology center (CNST) in Maryland.  The interns were placed in various technical divisions at NIST’s Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology for durations of 16 weeks.

 

Goal 5: Outreach and Public Awareness. Several outreach activities such as presentations, hands-on workshops and lectures to industrial partners, academic partners, and our broader stakeholder communities were offered during this reporting period. Science Discovery fairs for area schools, and other activities. During the period of the award more than 7,000 participants have befitted in these activities.

 

Goal 6: STEM Career Encouragement and Recruitment. NEATEC has been promoting specific activities to promote STEM careers (high-school to college pipeline)  to support our partner community colleges and partner industries. We are focused on incorporating our training and curricular development efforts within long-term sustainable programs offered through our partner community colleges and universities to promote STEM careers.  We have also leveraging these activities to promote the STEM workforce through training activities such as our Veterans training program with the U.S. Army’s Fort Drum Transition Assistance Program in Watertown, NY, and later with the Mohawk Valley Refugee Resource Center in Utica, NY.
